Jeff, I don't think we have any immediate plans to methodically test
the ad=
vantages or disadvantages of two outputs vs. a z input, or the
contribution=
 of direct connections or recurrence.  But even if we did
that in the check=
ers task there is no way to be sure whether the
results extend to other dom=
ains, so to get a really general sense of
which is better might take a lot =
of work over several domains.  Then
again, perhaps we'd notice something si=
gnificant just in checkers that
we don't realize so you never know, but at =
the moment I think we are
investigating too many other issues to really giv=
e that one sufficient
attention, even though it's interesting.  Hopefully s=
omeone else will
be interested enough to investigate it.

As I mentioned in=
 the other message on this thread, our aim in this
particular experiment wa=
s not really to evolve a fantastic checkers
player, but rather to just show=
 the advantage HyperNEAT provides by
learning from geometry.  Recall that N=
EAT could not even learn to
defeat the heuristic player at all in 20 runs, =
while HyperNEAT defeats
in around 8 or 9 generations on average!  That is q=
uite a disparity
and shows how important capturing the prevailing regularit=
y is in this
domain.  Later it will be interesting to see how well we can d=
o in a
absolute sense, but that's a different paper.

ken

yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:

> Hello all-
> 
> I enjoy=
ed reading the checkers paper and the reactions to it here on the
> forum. =

> 
> Does anyone have an immediate plan to test out different
configuratio=
ns for
> the CPPN? It would be interesting to see if the z approach does
be=
tter than
> the two output approach, and what would happen if direct links =
and
> recurrence were allowed.
> 
> Have you guys done any tests of the Hyp=
erNEAT evaluator vs.
Blondie24? How
> about vs. leading checkers AI program=
s?  I just browsed around and
could not
> (quickly) find out if xCheckers u=
ses what would be considered a
leading edge
> board evaluator. 
> 
> You me=
ntion below that it is difficult to evaluate your program against
> human p=
layers, but why not start by evaluating them against leading AI
> checkers =
programs? I know this comparison was not necessary for the
point
> you were=
 getting at in this paper, but it would be very interesting
to know
> how t=
he HyperNEAT evaluator fares against the current best AI
evaluators. I
> am=
 not sure what constitutes an exhaustive comparison between two
checkers
> =
evaluators (all possible opening move sets?), but I gathered from
your pape=
r
> that the test you conducted was more narrow than what I imagine would b=
e
> involved in a true head to head comparison of evaluators.
> 
> Finally,=
 while it is cool that your program beats you guys at
checkers, it
> might =
not solely be because of the HyperNEAT-driven AI. The program
is also
> usi=
ng alpha-beta and the like. I'll bet a rather poor position evaluator
> plu=
s Alpha-Beta with a decent amount of lookahead could beat me at
checkers,
>=
 even if I was better at evaluating board positions on average.
> 
> Thanks=
 again, it was a very enjoyable read. I also think it is great
that
> you g=
uys have decided to try to reposition this stuff to make
inroads back
> int=
o mainstream AI.
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune

igan State University

math2000@...>

 > Date: Sat, 12 Apr 2008 17:40:00 -0000

at@yahoogroups.com>

in of Checkers
> > 
> > Hey Stephen,
> > 
> > Great questions!  We'll have =
to think about some of them for awhile
> > but here's a few answers:
> > 
>=
 > The reason why I chose to use a separate output for each connection
> > =
layer instead of using a 3-dimensional CPPN is because I wanted to
> > sepa=
rate the network for each layer.  If you use the 3-D CPPN method,
> > then =
the two layers are only distinguished by the values of 'z'.
> > Because I'm=
 only using two layers, I wanted to make sure that each
> > layer did some =
unique processing.  If there was only one output, it
> > would be harder fo=
r the connection layers to distinguish themselves as
> > they would be too =
dependent.  In the worst case, z1 and z2 inputs are
> > not used and the tw=
o layers are exactly the same. I haven't done any
> > empirical tests on wh=
ich method is better so I do not have any
> > evidence to back my claim, bu=
t it's my intuition.
> > 
> > I haven't tried any computer opponents other =
than Xcheckers.  I have
> > had my friends and people in the lab play again=
st the HyperNEAT
> > opponent and it is definitely better than all of us :-=
).  I would like
> > to release a binary version so people can play the opp=
onents at
> > different generations and see the change in performance.
> > =

> > One active area of interest is to figure out how good a HyperNEAT
> > =
player is in a global sense.  In Chellapilla & Fogel's paper, they
> > play=
ed human opponents in checkers on MSN Gaming Zone online and got
> > an exp=
ert rating on that game server.  The problem with this is that
> > it is ve=
ry time consuming to play games by hand. It would not be
> > feasible for m=
e to test several individuals in this way.
> > 
> > I have experimented wit=
h coevolution, but I need to solve the
> > aforementioned problem before I =
can say anything about the performance
> > of the evolved individuals.
> > =

ial Intelligence (2008), "A Case Study on the

ric Regularity in Machine Learning."

aper, thanks Jason and Ken.

 Was the 4in/2out CPPN arbitrarily chosen?

xyz, out) - which seems more natural
to me?

onfiguration tried?  What was the process?
> >> * Was more than one substra=
te configuration tried?  ...

rough the substrate?  You
> >> mention the 129 nodes (which makes sense), b=
ut what are the 3979

ents other than Xcheckers?
